title: 115_hr4708
content:
The Department of Homeland Security Blue Campaign Authorization Act establishes the Blue Campaign within the Department to coordinate efforts against human trafficking. The program will be headed by a Director appointed by the Secretary with the purpose of unifying efforts in combating human trafficking. The Blue Campaign, established within the Department of Homeland Security, aims to unify and coordinate efforts to address human trafficking. The Secretary, through the Director, will issue guidance, develop training programs, coordinate departmental efforts, and provide guidance on trauma-informed practices for human trafficking victims. The Blue Campaign provides guidance and training to Department personnel and other law enforcement agencies on identifying human trafficking, collecting relevant information, sharing information, and identifying trafficking victims at border and airport security checkpoints. The Transportation Security Administration and other agencies are trained to identify human trafficking victims at border and airport security checkpoints. Resources like indicator cards and awareness campaigns are used to educate partners and increase public awareness. Partnerships with various organizations are leveraged to combat human trafficking. The Blue Campaign works with governmental, nongovernmental, and private sector organizations to raise public awareness of human trafficking. The Secretary may determine additional activities necessary for the campaign's implementation. A clerical amendment is made to the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include the Blue Campaign in the table of contents. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to integrate information technology systems within the Department to track individuals involved in human trafficking. Additionally, a report must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Homeland Security within 18 months of the enactment of the Act. The House of Representatives Committee on Homeland Security report describes the status and effectiveness of the Department of Homeland Security Blue Campaign and provides a recommendation for the appropriate office within the Department. $819,000 is authorized for carrying out section 434 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002.
